title: Everest report recommends partial rerouting of trail
text:
Everest report recommends partial rerouting of trail 11 August 2015 Save 
Experts are recommending rerouting a section of the Everest trail and relocating two villages in the wake of the Nepalese earthquake. 
A report commissioned by the government of Nepal saw nine major bridges assessed as well as 710 buildings in 15 local villages. 
It found that “minimal damage” was done to the majority of accommodation and trails in the Everest region, in Nepal’s northeast. 
However, in order to reduce risks to both tourists and locals alike, it adds part of the trail should be rerouted while buildings in the villages of Tok Tok and Benkar should be relocated to the other side of a river. 
The report, which has been welcomed in the country, also recommends a follow up engineering assessment after the monsoon. 
Ramesh Kumar Adhikari, administrative chief of Nepal Tourism Board, said: “Tourism is the largest employer in Nepal and it’s vital to our economic recovery. We know that Everest is a huge draw for visitors – it is a bucket list destination.” 
Tulasi Prasad Gautam, director general of the Department of Tourism, added: “The aim of the report was to develop an initial understanding of the extent of the damage from the earthquakes so that we could assess the overall safety of the Everest region’s trekking routes before the season starts in September.” 
It was also welcomed by Darrell Wade, chief executive and founder of Intrepid Travel, who added: “As far as we’re concerned the report is all good news, because even where it’s identified issues it means that we now have the information needed to rebuild Nepal stronger than ever before, and ensure the safety of our staff, travellers, and the local communities we visit.” 
The government report comes following last month’s one which identified “very little damage to the area in north-central Nepal, with the 3% of buildings damaged in the quake all ‘easily repairable’”.
